docs.lead_paragraph: The proposed $8.8 billion megamerger between Aetna and U.S. Healthcare would create a health plan of forbidding size, with over 20 million members in 50 states, including 650,000 members in New York City alone. But in health care, size is probably necessary to create the extended networks and information systems that improve quality. A merged Aetna-U.S. Healthcare would carry the financial strength that is needed in New York to give the likes of Oxford and HIP a run for their customers. Aetna is a traditional insurance company that until recently emphasized fee-for-service coverage. It has not been a leader in managed care, which now covers most people whose health coverage is provided by their employers.
docs.snippet: The proposed $8.8 billion megamerger between Aetna and U.S. Healthcare would  create a health plan of forbidding size, with over 20 million members in 50 states, including 650,000 members in New York City alone. But in health care, size is probably...

docs.lead_paragraph: Even though the Aetna Life and Casualty Company is buying U.S. Healthcare Inc., the impact in the New York metropolitan region will probably make it seem as if the opposite has occurred. The U.S. Healthcare network -- it is both far larger and more successful, with about four times as many managed care patients as Aetna in New York State, for example -- is expected to provide the imprint for how the two companies march forward together. "It makes U.S. Healthcare even more of what they were -- a strong competitor in the market," said Jim Tallon, president of United Hospital Fund, a nonprofit philanthropic and medical research organization based in New York City.

headline.main: In New York, Aetna Will Be Understudy
headline.kicker: A MERGER OF HEALTH INSURERS: THE REGION

docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to exit a money-losing business and to avoid lengthy and potentially costly lawsuits from investors, the New York Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it planned to liquidate limited energy and real estate partnerships and repay every investor in the partnerships. The proposal covers $396 million in a total of 28 partnerships sold by the company's broker-dealer subsidiary, NYLife Securities Inc., between 1985 and 1992 and in which New York Life affiliates served as a general partner.

headline.main: New York Life in Partnership Liquidations

docs.snippet: Seeking to exit a money-losing business and to avoid lengthy and potentially  costly lawsuits from investors, the New York Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it planned to liquidate limited energy and real estate partnerships and repay every...

docs.lead_paragraph: Leonard Abramson decided about a year ago that U.S. Healthcare Inc., his enormously successful health maintenance organization, needed a new strategy to keep its profits up. A flock of competing H.M.O.'s, led by Oxford Health Systems, was vying for customers on his home turf, in Philadelphia and New Jersey. Even more threatening, hospitals and doctors were melding into groups big enough to resist when the H.M.O.'s try to squeeze their fees. Mr. Abramson, the founder and chief executive of U.S. Healthcare, turned over daily operations to his lieutenants and set out to find a strategic partner. He ended up selling his managed care company to the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, he said yesterday, to get the "mass we needed, the power to negotiate with the physicians, the hospitals, the drug companies" and force down their charges.

headline.main: Managed Care Empires in the Making
headline.kicker: A MERGER OF HEALTH INSURERS: THE INDUSTRY

docs.lead_paragraph: Connecticut's Insurance Department today approved the Aetna Life and Casualty Company's $4 billion sale of its property-casualty business to Travelers Group Inc. The approval was the final regulatory hurdle for the deal, which creates the nation's fourth-largest insurer of buildings, automobiles and businesses. A few finishing touches have to be worked out by the companies, a spokesman for Aetna said. Travelers will form a holding company, based in Hartford, to operate the companies' combined property-casualty operations. As many as 3,300 jobs at the new entity will be eliminated, with half the cuts to be made in Hartford, Travelers has said. The consolidation is expected to result in hundreds of millions of dollars in savings for the new company.

docs.lead_paragraph: TO the uninitiated, it might look like a strategy of sell low and buy high. That is not the way they see it at Aetna Life and Casualty, where Ronald E. Compton, the chairman and president, exuded happiness yesterday as he explained the acquisition of U.S. Healthcare, the managed care company. Much of the money for the purchase came from selling Aetna's property and casualty business.

headline.main: Market Place;Aetna's game plan will be a case for the business school books.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company plans to spend $8.8 billion to buy U.S. Healthcare Inc., a leader in what is known as managed health care, creating the nation's single biggest medical benefits company. The combined company will cover 23 million people, or one in every 12 Americans, offering everything from health and disability protection to prescriptions, mental health, vision, dental care as well as retirement services. It will be the fourth-largest company in the country operating health maintenance organizations, which try to keep down medical costs by negotiating with doctors and hospitals for lower charges and controlling patients' access to health care services.

headline.main: Aetna to Buy U.S. Healthcare In Big Move to Managed Care

docs.lead_paragraph: In the small world of geneticists in the forefront of studying human disease, the researchers tend to know one another. So last year, after the discovery that as many as 1 percent of Jewish women carry a mutated form of a gene that might predispose them to breast and ovarian cancer, it was easy enough for leading scientists and two major commercial testing labs to agree informally not to offer the test to the general public. The reasoning was that many questions remained about the risk posed by the gene, about what, if anything, could be done to lessen the risk and about whether widespread testing would do more harm than good.

headline.main: Breaking Ranks, Lab Offers Test To Assess Risk of Breast Cancer

docs.lead_paragraph: The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, the state's largest and oldest health maintenance organization, routinely fails to pay millions of dollars of its members' medical bills each year, leaving subscribers either to cover the bills themselves or to fight collection agencies and lawsuits from doctors demanding overdue payments. An analysis of records filed with the New York State Department of Insurance, as well as H.I.P.'s own financial reports, show that the H.M.O. has for years delayed paying for treatment it authorized outside of its regular network of doctors, therapists and hospitals, including emergency appendectomies and bypass surgery, specialized physical therapy and doctors' visits when patients fall ill far from home.

headline.main: PAST DUE -- A special report.;DELAYS BY H.M.O. LEAVING PATIENTS HAUNTED BY BILLS
